Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2010 11:32AM GryffinSong wrote: I'm so sorry you're going through this. The waiting is so hard. I agree with thenewme that distraction is good. I also clicked into "problem solving mode" and did tons of research so I'd be well prepared for the next step. I found that the more I learned the more I felt in control of the process. That doesn't mean I wasn't terrified, and crying everyday. But at least I felt better able to make decisions when they came up. For instance, with your family history, do you want another lumpectomy, or would you consider mastectomy? These were questions I asked myself and read about. Whatever happens, and whatever decisions you make, major hugs and best wishes!!!

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2008 05:20PM GryffinSong wrote: I have no idea, but I would certainly call my doctor to ask them. Please call to find out, if only to ease your mind.
Posts.Title: Worried MariaCcortez GryffinSong

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2008 09:41PM GryffinSong wrote: Waiting for test results, as the others have said, is absolutely the very worst part. For me, it was about being out of control. Having no say in what was going on inside my body. Just waiting for information. My testing is finally done, and now I feel great. I do have cancer, but now that I know the general extent of it, I can finally start making decisions. It's a powerful feeling. Finally I have some real say in what happens, because I've identified the enemy! I hope yours is benign, and if it isn't, you've found an awesome resource here in getting through the process. Hugs and best of luck!!! :)
Posts.Title: feeling lonely,nervous,anxiety ridden auntiekayro GryffinSong

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2008 10:28PM GryffinSong wrote: I agree with Alicia. If it is something other than a simple pimple or whatever, the sooner you get it checked the better off you'll be. Hugs and good luck!
Posts.Title: I'm not really sure what to think RobynS GryffinSong

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2008 03:45PM GryffinSong wrote: Your body has changed, and you've fought a nasty monster. You have every right to feel whatever you're feeling. Please don't worry if you don't feel happy yet. Its your illness, and you will deal with it in your own time. For what its worth, although I haven't seen your scars, I have seen other's breast cancer scars. To me, they look beautiful! Why? Because I see them as an outward sign of courage, of triumph over evil, and as a reminder that we can survive and move on. I hope your husband and you find the courage to look at your scar with love and acceptance. It might take some time, but you have survived, and that's a beautiful thing!!! In the meantime, accept your feelings, whatever they are, and allow yourself to grieve over the changes, and your losses. It's perfectly natural, and you deserve to take that time to heal, emotionally as well as physically. Hugs and good luck!!!
Posts.Title: Is my mx scar normal? digger BethNY

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2010 05:28PM GryffinSong wrote: I was really glad I had mine because I'm a really tough stick. I had a few problems. The first one they put in had a crimp in the line so I had to go through surgery twice. And once it clogged, but they were able to get it running. I had some itching. I have small dogs who jump up on me. When they hit the port it hurt. It looked funny, and now, months after having it removed, the scar on my neck is pretty obvious. The other scar doesn't bother me as much because it's down below my shirt line. Sorry that's kind of a negative set of things, but overall I was really glad to have it. Sticks were so easy and I never had to worry about my veins giving out. Hugs and good luck to you!!!

If you have the inclination and time, offers to drive her to appointments, gifts of scarves if she loses her hair, a phone call just to check on her. Once she's in the fight against cancer, all those things will be precious to her. Do you know that she's stage IV? If so, you might want to post in the stage IV forum here. Those ladies will know more details about what she can expect. Hugs to her and to you for helping her!

I had both breasts removed with no reconstruction, so am not sure I can help you. But if I were in your shoes I'd call your doctor. There's no need for you to sit and worry ... that's what they're there for ... to help you with your questions, and they'll know better than we will. Hugs and good luck!!!
Posts.Title: healing from a mastectomy Chadneyann Moderators

I always press my doctors to give me percentage improvements on recurrance, since sometimes they're just focused on longterm survival. I want to only fight this beast once. ;) Hugs and good luck!!!
Posts.Title: Lymph Node removal AFTER chemo Everett78 GryffinSong

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2010 07:11PM GryffinSong wrote: I don't have any advice. Just hugs and encouragement to talk with your surgeon about this idea. I think given time and the difficulties you're having, your surgeon is the fastest, best way to give you some ideas on pros and cons. For me, I chose the bilateral mastectomy with no recon and I'm very comfortable with my decision. I haven't missed my "girls" at all. Part of my decision-making process was that I didn't want rads. Unfortunately, I had node involvement, so I wound up with chemo and rads anyway.
Posts.Title: Quitting rads to get mastectomy instead? Raili 1marmalade1

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2010 12:25PM GryffinSong wrote: I thought I was in a gray area too, but I think it depends on your physician. My radiologist said it could go either way, but my new oncologist says he would definately have recommended it, so I'm glad I did. My thinking was that I wanted every ounce of preventative that I could get. And other than the inconvenience of being every day, it only takes a few minutes, and the added security and peace of mind feels very worth it to me. Rads aren't bad at all compared to chemo. I got a slight burn, but lots of aloe vera and various lotions got me through. That side looks great now, and you'd never know I'd had it done by my skin condition. Hugs and good luck!
Posts.Title: Radiation for close margin after mastectomy and chemo? michelle_nj michelle_nj

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 11:55PM GryffinSong wrote: I don't know yet what my options are, but if I have the option, I'm probably going for bilateral mastectomy. Why? Because I'm only 51, but have really bad bone density. A friend of mine lost 25% of her bone during chemo. I can't afford to lose ANY more bone than I already have. In addition, the worry factor, and the time-intensive schedule for chemo and/or radiation are factors for me. Winter is coming on here, and with snow I might not be able to get into town everyday for treatment.
Posts.Title: For those who "could" have Lumpectomy.... why choose Mast? Estepp sbmolee

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2008 12:46PM GryffinSong wrote: Hugs to you sammie! I went for several years without a doctor because I was traveling fulltime in my RV and didn't know who to go to. I asked many people for recommendations, and am really happy with the doc I found. Hopefully you have friends, particularly women friends, who can recommend a doctor for you. As for the changes, there can be changes that the breasts go through during your cycle, but checking it out is always a good idea. I wish you luck! Try not to worry too much, and I hope you can find a doctor you like. My new doctor is so fabulous that I feel really supported in my journey. A doctor can be an excellent resource. I know the odds are miniscule, but if you're anywhere near the Spokane, WA area please contact me and I can give you some suggestions.
Posts.Title: Very worried,please help sammie08 sammie08

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2009 06:20PM GryffinSong wrote: I went under for a bilateral mastectomy, believing I had a "simple" stage 1 cancer. I woke to the news that three nodes were positive, and one of them had started to spread. That pushed me to stage 2, and all of a sudden I was facing chemo and rads, instead of "just" surgery. That was a tough day, but I got through it. Chemo was REALLY hard on me, rads not so much. Now I'm on tamoxifen, and if they can get my bone density up over the next couple of years, they'll switch me to an aromitase inhibitor. It's good to "meet" all of you!

You might check to see if your local group has such a person. I found them very helpful in understanding what was possible and in filling out all the paperwork. Hugs and good luck!
Posts.Title: What if.. vickib GryffinSong

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2009 03:58PM GryffinSong wrote: Thanks for the warm welcome! I do have osteopenia, which is the precursor to osteoporosis. My last test, taken a month or two ago, is -2.2. A year ago was -1.9. Osteoporosis starts at -2.5. My hair is lush, wavy, and much whiter than it used to be. But it seems to be coming in darker underneath. It's perhaps an inch and a half or more now and I'm contemplating a trim!  :) Never thought I'd feel that way, as my hair was halfway down my back when I was diagnosed. Stephanie, my nodes were the same: one sentinal and two other. The sentinal node was the one that had "burst" already, though they said the spread was VERY tiny.

Posts.Title: Silly question, but.... joyko GryffinSong

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2008 09:31PM GryffinSong wrote: Sorry to hear what you're going through. I concur with car, and would not consider reconstruction unless it was with a really good and experienced surgeon. It's a specialty type of thing, and you don't want someone messing it up. You can always reconstruct later, so perhaps you should do the mastectomy now, and consider your options later. I have a friend whose tumor was about the size of yours. She had a single mastectomy, and chose to wait for reconstruction. She's wishing, now, that she'd had both breasts removed. She did need chemo, and is free of cancer now, two years later. Hugs and best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed with Cancer Carolyn2008 Carolyn2008

Posts.Content: GryffinSong wrote: I had my MRI today, which was an interesting experience. Just when I'd start to relax and get my breathing under control, the sounds of machine gun fire would start up again! Wow, that thing is loud! Reading off my sheet, before the MRI, they said I had invasive carcinoma. They did not tell me whether it was lobular or ductal. I was so hoping it would be in situ, and I'm trying not to worry too much. My surgical consult is monday, where I'll find out the full details. I just have to make it through the weekend without worrying myself to death. I really, really hate that "invasive" word. They told me it was low grade, so my worry had gone down a few notches to a mere simmer. Now its raging again. :( bmx, no recon - December 16, 2008, AC/T, rads Dx 11/4/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 3/18 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: MRI Today GryffinSong GryffinSong

This forum is very helpful, but sometimes we just need a real hug or talk with a "real" person. :) It's a tough road, but there are lots of people ahead of us, and walking beside us. I wish you all the luck in the world, and can attest that waiting is one of the hardest parts of the process.

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2010 09:27PM GryffinSong wrote: groundhog, I believe that ACT (in whatever combination) has been the standard of care for diagnoses like ours for a decade or so. If I'm remembering correctly, TC was an option for me until they found out that I had node involvement, pushing me to stage 2. Unless I'm mistaken, my oncologist said TC was only for very early cancers, and I no longer qualified. I could be mis-remembering, but it's worth asking more questions about the pros and cons of the two protocols, and how your onc might advise you to decide. Hugs and good luck!

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2010 06:39PM GryffinSong wrote: Whatever you say, please be honest with them. Leave some things out if you truly must, but kids know a lot more than we give them credit for. I remember when I my aunt died of breast cancer. My brother and I, who were young teens, knew what was going on. My cousins had not even been told she had cancer. We arrived for a visit and to help her, but she was in the hospital. My brother and I knew she might not come home. Because all the adults had gone to the hospital, it was left to my bro and I to break it to our cousins that my aunt was terminally ill. It was awful, and my cousins felt totally betrayed by their parents for not sharing the truth with them. Hugs and best wishes in dealing with this!!!

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2009 04:33PM GryffinSong wrote: I'm so sorry for those who are worried about insurance and finances. I find they're almost scarier than the health issues themselves. :( I had my first bout of vomiting last night. Nausea had been minimal, but I got cocky, and didn't take anything before bedtime. I also was fighting off a migraine, and I think the two combined did me in. I was fine a short while later. Took some Zomig for the migraine, and both my nausea meds, and I was able to sleep. This sunday I shave my head. Wednesday is my second treatment of AC. Hugs and good luck to all!!!

Posts.Title: What was your favorite head covering through chemo? BooBee Brendatrue

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2010 11:26AM GryffinSong wrote: I LOVE being boobless! No worries (well, fewer worries), no bouncing, no bra, no nipples showing, etc. Every insurance company is different, as is every state and country's guidelines. The best thing to do is talk in detail with your surgeon, and the financial support team at your cancer center or hospital. They will know, for your area and situation, what might be possible. Given your repeated scares, I'd think that at prophylactic mastectomy is a very reasonable approach, and hopefully your insurance will see it that way. Hugs and good luck!!!

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2009 11:57PM GryffinSong wrote: Hi all, and hugs to all! I'm scheduled to have my port put in this friday morning. I also just found out (yesterday) that I'll need radiation after chemo. Sigh. I'm now trying to decide between TAC, a study that''ll give me either TAC or just TC, and something called dose dense, that would give me AC every two weeks for four weeks, and then taxol every two weeks for four weeks. I don't know how to decide ... any suggestions? Thanks!
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2009 04:31PM GryffinSong wrote: Hi all, I am SO far behind on the net, I apologize for not having read through the half of the thread that I hadn't read earlier. I had my first chemo treatment a week ago. So far I'm ok. Some queasy feelings, but no out-and-out nausea. I feel tired. This morning I woke with swollen gums and a mild fever, but not up to the 100.4 threshold where they want to do anything about it. I had a fair amount of pain from the Neulasta shot, mostly in my neck. But feel pretty lucky overall. My treatment regimen is the "dose-dense" AC every 2 weeks for 4 treatments, then taxol every two weeks for 4 treatments. The process was fine. I thought I was going to have to do it alone, but a friend showed up in the parking lot and stayed with me. Yay for friends!!! I also had trouble with my first port. It had a kink in the line, and nothing could get through it, so I had to have another surgery to replace it. Surgery was last tuesday, chemo the next day. I have to go to town today to refill a prescription (so I'm at the library on the way). My computer seems to be shot, so unfortunately I can't read/write as much as I'd like. I plan to shave my head this sunday with a friend. My mom and several friends have made hats for me, and although I'm dreading being hairless, I feel so blessed for the folks who are gifting me with hats to cheer me up and keep me warm and protected. I'll make a rather vague offer, because I know I'll have way more hats than I'll need. One friend is sending me NINE hats!!! If anyone here is tight on funds and needs a hat to keep their noggin warm, please PM me. I will gladly pass on a few "spares" to those in need. Please use the PM rather than posting a reply, simply because I can't keep up and might miss it. Hugs to all, and I know we can do this!!!
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2009 06:19PM - edited Feb 16, 2009 06:23PM by GryffinSong Yes. After four treatments of AC I'll have four more treatments of Taxol. Then radiation starts, after a break. I'm glad you mentioned the heartburn, because I have that feeling a lot. It's more a feeling of fullness all the way up my chest, which is helping me eat less. I buzzed my hair off yesterday. Met with two friends, buzzed the sides. Then we french braided the center section ( my hair was halfway down my back ) so that I looked like a mongol warrior. Photographed it, and buzzed the rest. To be honest, I rather like it. Sort of fresh and innocent looking. Even though I'm 51 and have a few "life lines" (wrinkles) I have really large, round, grayish blue eyes that give me a bit of a pixie look. Fun. We laughed, we hugged, we ate pizza. Now I'm off to catch up on the rest of this thread. :)

I would think a week or two would be plenty to wait, but again, ask them to be sure. Hugs and good luck!!!

Posts.Title: Frustrated With Recovery flb1011 2Hands4me

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2008 05:20AM GryffinSong wrote: Hi there! You have a right to see all your test results, and to ask any question you've got. It's your body, and you have the right to see everything. And, if they don't move as aggressively or as fast as you want, you also have a right to a second opinion. I'm not a big fan of "wait and see", so am glad they're finally looking for answers. Hugs and good luck to you!!! :)
Posts.Title: Another Question kelsgotacamera kelsgotacamera

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2010 09:43PM GryffinSong wrote: This is a really personal decision that differs for everyone. Things to think about include how worried you'll be if you retain the breast, how important your breasts are to you. How well you tolerate surgery. Mastectomy is a more complex and longer surgery, but you'll never have a mammogram on that side again. I'm glad I chose bilateral mastectomy. I'm even from side to side, and feel relieved not to have regular mammograms and to have so little breast tissue to worry about. Some feel the opposite, and are glad to retain most of their natural tissue. Try to think about what your breasts mean to you. How important are they to your life, your self esteem, and personal relationship you're in. If you have a partner, discuss it and see if it matters to them and how you feel about that. If you don't have a partner, how might you feel in future, meeting someone new. All can factor into your decision.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy VS Lumpectomy yunlee72 PiscesMoon

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2010 12:21AM GryffinSong wrote: For what its worth, I wanted a bilateral mastectomy, and that's what I got. I had my surgery a little over a year ago, on december 16. I have never once regretted it. I didn't even choose to reconstruct, and feel freer without breasts to worry about. I knew that I'd always be worried about cancer striking again. I still worry, but with all/most of my breast tissue removed I don't worry nearly as much. Do what YOU need to do to feel comfortable, whether it's a lumpectomy or mastectomy. It's your body. Hugs and good luck!!!
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy vs Mastectomy mom2mms SATEX12

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2008 07:27PM GryffinSong wrote: I'm only ten days post surgery, but have not missed my breasts at all. I've looked at my chest every day since surgery, and besides thinking it looks bizarre in its current state of puffy, slightly bruised, taped, stitched bumpiness, it doesn't bother me to look at it at all. I can't imagine, for me, going through further surgery, pain, and recovery just to have them back, especially if they feel as oddly tingly/numb as my chest feels now!!! Hugs to all, no matter their recon decisions!!! :)
Posts.Title: reconstruction or not ????? vivianu spar2

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2008 12:50AM GryffinSong wrote: I'm about where you are. I have no expanders, but am still tired and not expecting much of myself. I, too, still have drains in. One or two are ready (or nearly ready) to come out, but we're snowed in here, and not taking chances on the icy roads. The edges of the skin where the drains come out are irritated, and I'm not sleeping all that well because they easily get ouchy. From everything I've heard, I wouldn't expect to be able to work a full day until 6-8 weeks out.
Posts.Title: Frustrated With Recovery flb1011 2Hands4me

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2011 09:11PM GryffinSong wrote: So glad it went well for you! I chose not to reconstruct and I've never even considered wearing a prosthetic. It's so wonderfully freeing to have no worries about bras, and I'm quite sure that the band would bother my lymphedema under my arm, so it's nice not having that worry. I love being breast-free. :) Hugs and best of luck to you in your recovery!!! And, yeah, I'm with you that the bra woman was completely out of line.

That's how I've been feeling in making my decision, and I'm happy to hear that you still feel like that post-surgery. I go in a week from today for my surgery, so next week I'll be breast free, and hopefully will feel as liberated as you feel. :)
Posts.Title: reconstruction or not ????? vivianu spar2

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2010 07:07PM GryffinSong wrote: My breast surgeon once said something that I'll never forget. She said until you have tissue in your hands to test, you can't be 100% certain of anything. I hate biopsies with a passion. The needles, the fear of seeding a new site, the waiting for results. But a biopsy totally rocks in terms of useful information. I would insist. Hugs and best wishes!!!

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2008 09:25PM GryffinSong wrote: I'm so sorry you're getting the runaround! I feel for you, and hope that you can get answers quickly.
Posts.Title: This waiting is insane..... pashari buffy

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 10:58PM GryffinSong wrote: I'm so glad to see this topic. I'm in the early stages of diagnosis, but am leaning strongly toward double mastectomy with NO reconstruction. I'd rather be flat chested than worry about complications with a rebuild. It especially freaks me out that there would be damage to healthy muscle and such to make a fake boob. No thanks!!! ;) Thanks to all of you for sharing your stories.
Posts.Title: reconstruction or not ????? vivianu spar2

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2008 03:49PM GryffinSong wrote: jkfran, waiting is an entirely reasonable thing to do if you're not sure yet. My surgeon was very supportive when I said I didn't want reconstruction, and made it very clear that if I changed my mind in future, we could do something then. The overwhelmed feeling is so common, and so devastating. I think giving yourself time to adapt, by taking it one step at a time, makes perfect sense. Hugs and good luck!
Posts.Title: reconstruction or not ????? vivianu spar2

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2008 06:27PM GryffinSong wrote: "Gryffin Song,  How are u feeling after 10 days.  How's it going with the drains.  I am very nervous about that.  I guess it just something else to focus on. " Physically, I feel quite good. I can walk around, do minor tasks, carry light things, and so on. The drains are a little uncomfortable, and I'm hoping to get one or two of them out tomorrow. I'm off of pain meds for the most part. The overall experience hasn't been too bad. I'm able to look at myself, and at the stuff draining out, but sometimes feel frightened and lost. The surgery itself, emotionally speaking, seems to be the least of my problem. More difficult, for me, is the feeling of my life being out of control, of having failed the last few years of my life, and fears around taking care of myself, especially during a difficult winter without my full strength. I'm very glad I chose not to reconstruct, because the pain is minimal, and I'm not having any of the issues that recon patients seem to have with pain and such. Hugs and good luck!
Posts.Title: reconstruction or not ????? vivianu spar2

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2009 01:05PM GryffinSong wrote: Hi Pamela, You're so lucky to get out your drains so soon. I'm two and a half weeks out and two of my drains are STILL outputting too much fluid!!! The one I've had removed was SO relieving. Everyone is right when they say you'll feel tons better with them removed. As for reconstruction, the only bad moment I've had was last night. I'm still staying with a friend right now, because it's been snowing so much that I'd have trouble dealing with it on my own. There were three teenagers here last night, and they were telling a joke about bra sizes. After they left the room I felt myself all weepy, thinking, but I have no bra size. First time I've felt sad at all about losing my breasts, and it isn't bothering me this morning at all. My fears about lymphedema are still much more immediate than loss of my breasts, since I had all my nodes removed on the right side.
Posts.Title: reconstruction or not ????? vivianu spar2
